questions.question: Point $(-3, 5)$ lies in the
questions.solution: In the point $(-3, 5)$, the abscissa is negative ($x < 0$) and the ordinate is positive ($y > 0$). Therefore, it lies in the second quadrant.

questions.question: Signs of the abscissa and ordinate of a point in the second quadrant are respectively
questions.solution: In the second quadrant, x-coordinate (abscissa) is negative and y-coordinate (ordinate) is positive. So, the signs are –, +.

questions.question: Point $(0, -7)$ lies
questions.solution: Since the x-coordinate (abscissa) is zero, the point lies on the y-axis.

questions.question: Point $(-10, 0)$ lies
options: (A) on the negative direction of the x-axis
(B) on the negative direction of the y-axis
questions.solution: Since the y-coordinate is zero, the point lies on the x-axis. Since the x-coordinate is negative ($-10$), it lies on the negative direction of the x-axis.

questions.question: Abscissa of all the points on the x-axis is
questions.solution: On the x-axis, the y-coordinate (ordinate) is always 0, but the x-coordinate (abscissa) can be any number.

questions.question: Ordinate of all points on the x-axis is
questions.solution: The perpendicular distance of any point on the x-axis from the x-axis itself is 0. Thus, the ordinate is 0.

questions.question: The point at which the two coordinate axes meet is called the
questions.solution: The intersection point of the x-axis and y-axis is called the origin, with coordinates $(0, 0)$.

questions.question: A point both of whose coordinates are negative will lie in
questions.solution: If both coordinates are negative ($x < 0, y < 0$), the point lies in the III quadrant.

questions.question: Points $(1, -1), (2, -2), (4, -5), (-3, -4)$
options: (D) do not lie in the same quadrant
questions.solution:
$(1, -1), (2, -2), (4, -5)$ lie in the IV quadrant ($x>0, y<0$).
$(-3, -4)$ lies in the III quadrant ($x<0, y<0$).
Therefore, they do not lie in the same quadrant.

questions.question: If y-coordinate of a point is zero, then this point always lies
questions.solution: Points with y-coordinate equal to zero are of the form $(x, 0)$, which lie on the x-axis.

questions.question: The points $(-5, 2)$ and $(2, -5)$ lie in the
questions.solution:
$(-5, 2)$ has $x<0, y>0$, so it is in the II quadrant.
$(2, -5)$ has $x>0, y<0$, so it is in the IV quadrant.

questions.question: If the perpendicular distance of a point P from the x-axis is 5 units and the foot of the perpendicular lies on the negative direction of x-axis, then the point P has
questions.solution: The perpendicular distance from the x-axis is the magnitude of the y-coordinate ($|y| = 5$). So $y = 5$ or $y = -5$. The foot lying on the negative x-axis implies the x-coordinate is negative, but the question asks about the property of P's coordinates. The most accurate description of P's y-coordinate is 5 or -5.

questions.question: On plotting the points $O(0, 0), A(3, 0), B(3, 4), C(0, 4)$ and joining OA, AB, BC and CO which of the following figure is obtained?
questions.solution: OA lies on the x-axis (length 3). OC lies on the y-axis (length 4). B is at $(3, 4)$. The figure has opposite sides equal ($OA=CB=3, OC=AB=4$) and all angles are $90^\circ$. It is a Rectangle.

questions.question: If $P(-1, 1), Q(3, -4), R(1, -1), S(-2, -3)$ and $T(-4, 4)$ are plotted on the graph paper, then the point(s) in the fourth quadrant are
questions.solution:
Fourth quadrant points have signs $(+, -)$.
$Q(3, -4)$ and $R(1, -1)$ satisfy this condition.

questions.question: If the coordinates of the two points are $P(-2, 3)$ and $Q(-3, 5)$, then (abscissa of P) – (abscissa of Q) is
questions.solution:
Abscissa of P = $-2$.
Abscissa of Q = $-3$.
Difference = $(-2) - (-3) = -2 + 3 = 1$.

questions.question: If $P(5, 1), Q(8, 0), R(0, 4), S(0, 5)$ and $O(0, 0)$ are plotted on the graph paper, then the point(s) on the x-axis are
questions.solution:
Points on the x-axis have y-coordinate equal to 0.
$Q(8, 0)$ and $O(0, 0)$ satisfy this.

questions.question: Abscissa of a point is positive in
questions.solution: Abscissa ($x$) is positive in the I and IV quadrants (to the right of the y-axis).

questions.question: The points whose abscissa and ordinate have different signs will lie in
questions.solution:
Different signs mean $(-, +)$ or $(+, -)$.
$( -, + )$ is II quadrant.
$( +, - )$ is IV quadrant.
So, II and IV quadrants.

questions.question: In Fig. 3.1, coordinates of P are
questions.solution: From the figure, point P is in the II quadrant. Its distance from the y-axis is 2 units (so $x = -2$) and from the x-axis is 4 units (so $y = 4$). Coordinates are (-2, 4).

questions.question: In Fig. 3.2, the point identified by the coordinates $(-5, 3)$ is
questions.solution: The coordinates $(-5, 3)$ correspond to $x = -5$ and $y = 3$. This point lies in the II quadrant. In the figure, point L corresponds to this position.

questions.question: The point whose ordinate is 4 and which lies on y-axis is
questions.solution: A point on the y-axis has abscissa $x = 0$. Given ordinate $y = 4$. So the point is (0, 4).

questions.question: Which of the points $P(0, 3), Q(1, 0), R(0, -1), S(-5, 0), T(1, 2)$ do not lie on the x-axis?
questions.solution:
Points on the x-axis must have $y = 0$.
$Q(1, 0)$ and $S(-5, 0)$ lie on the x-axis.
$P(0, 3), R(0, -1), T(1, 2)$ do not lie on the x-axis.

questions.question: The point which lies on y-axis at a distance of 5 units in the negative direction of y-axis is
questions.solution:
Lies on y-axis $\Rightarrow x = 0$.
Negative direction of y-axis at distance 5 $\Rightarrow y = -5$.
Point is (0, -5).

questions.question: The perpendicular distance of the point P (3, 4) from the y-axis is
questions.solution:
The perpendicular distance of a point $(x, y)$ from the y-axis is given by its abscissa $|x|$.
Here, distance = $|3| = 3$.
